ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: A better understanding of how to use ArcGIS to perform simple tasks.
Learned about the basics of working in ArcGIS. The topics covered in class were mostly concerned with the basic operations one needs to manipulate data and visuals in the platform.
This class is a great introduction to GIS for anyone who is hoping to learn how to use the software for a job/research/other project.
Learned to use arcGIS software
Basic skills in using ArcGIS Pro. We focused on raster data and learned a lot of the fundamental tools for manipulating and presenting data.
I learned how to use GIS in a basic sense
how to use ArcGIS pro, different GIS operations, how to think about geography and GIS in an organized and insightful way

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I'm not sure if this is due to zoom, but it was a seminar of 10 students and there was no interaction ever. Even the first day there wasn't the typical, "let's go around and introduce ourselves". It was straight into lecture and that never changed.

The class is unique in that it is one of the few classes which focus solely on ArcGIS, so having the opportunity to learn about the platform from a professor who knows a great deal about the platform is quite valuable. Professor Tomlin does a great job of keeping the lessons straightforward and does a great deal of work to make sure the supporting materials for each lecture are clear and helpful. If there is a weakness to the class it is probably the pace of learning, I would have preferred to learn and work with more advanced operations or aspects of the program at the latter portion of the semester, but felt that the later portions of the curriculum did not challenge us sufficiently.

Weaknesses: There are no grades / no feedback on the assignments throughout the semester. 
Strengths: If students ask for feedback, Professor Tomlin will be incredibly responsive and provide very helpful support and feedback for the final project.

The class is focused on PSETs that provide a lot of good, hands-on experience with ArcGIS Pro. This culminates in a final project, which lets you go in-depth with a topic that interests you. Because the PSETs are such a focus, you can feel pretty distant from the class and the instructors.
Weaknesses - grades only based on the final project, don't get feedback on weekly homeworks, final projects are based on ranking among students. Extremely difficult to stay engaged.

It kind of blows to not have any feedback all semester...homework is for completion and it doesnt feel like he looks at it for how well done it is. Also, no guidelines for the final project, or instructions.

Strengths: The class was effective in teaching the basics of GIS. The materials in the tutorials was especially helpful. Extra material made available to the class generally was really great.
Weaknesses: the lecture format is not very engaging, and isn't very helpful overall. Even though all the information is there, the way it is posed just wasn't effective for me. Technical issues also posed an issue- unavoidable, but made it more challenging to take anything from lectures. A cut-down, prerecorded lecture would have been better, probably. As it was, the tutorials and other written material were more than enough to aid me in understanding GIS.

Another weakness was not receiving any feedback on any of the weekly homework assignments. It made it difficult to know how I was progressing, and felt like my effort and time wasn't being valued. There was little guidance given on the specifics of the term project, and the class syllabus wasn't helpful in this regard. The class also didn't use the Canvas page, and all material was distributed and received through a shared Google Drive. This was fine, but inconvenient at times, especially when trying to join a Zoom lecture (had to use a link sent from the professor's non-Yale email the first week of class).

The grading scheme is the obvious downside, with your entire grade being determined by your final project even though there is still other homework. Also, Professor Tomlin isn't always the most engaging lecturer, and he doesn't give much feedback at all. However, he really knows his stuff (he's a giant in the field!) and is super helpful in office hours and over email. Also, his weekly tutorials are well-designed and very helpful. And, the homeworks help you build up to your project in a good way.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The class could be greatly improved over zoom. No student interaction ever, never even heard over half the students talk in a seminar.
The fact that Professor Tomlin recorded the lectures and provided supporting documents for each lesson helped to maintain the pace of learning one might have for an in-person version of the class.

Having the lecture recordings available was really helpful! I did wish though that we'd been able to move the class to a later time though - it's such a small class and no one has travel constraints on zoom, and I found the 9:25am time pretty difficult.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: No, as of writing this course assessment, I have yet to receive any feedback on my work. It's not like we haven't had any work, we've had weekly assignments, but of these assignments, I have yet to receive a single grade or ounce of feedback as to whether my work is meeting expectations. Extremely frustrating and unusual.

If someone has a reason to think that they might want to learn ArcGIS (e.g. potential job requirement, usage for an academic project) this class is definitely preferable to learning ArcGIS on your own. Otherwise, this might not be a great use of your time if you both think you'll never use ArcGIS and are heavily considering other classes.
If you're hoping to learn GIS for a job/research/other project, this class is a great introduction.

It's good to learn some foundational skills in GIS. You don't necessarily get super deep into the software, but I think that's just a limitation of learning a program like this in class. I enjoyed the course and I think it's a good setup to doing further work in GIS.

No. It wasn't engaging. Maybe this is because of COVID and zoom classes but it was not engaging, and the grade only comprising of the final project in which students are ranked against each other is highly stressful.
I would recommend this course since it is effective at teaching GIS, with the caveat that self-directed learning with material provided will probably be the best way to approach the class.
Take it if you have a lot of internal motivation & curiosity for GIS as well as a lot of patience.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Recorded long seminars
Most of the class was taught by handouts
lecture was offered live but I typically watched the recording
Professor Tomlin also recorded his lectures so we could watch later if needed.
